p: The default cull radius of 75m as used in the front-end was chosen to emphasise how stochasticity can affect the effectiveness of a single control scenario when all parameters are fixed. We show here the results from this scenario, using fixed default epidemiological and control parameters (see Table 1), as seen by the user of our front-end interface. Control efficacy is extremely variable (Fig 7a and 7b). The realisation shown in Fig 7a leads to fewer than 10% of hosts (159 from 2000) removed before eradication at 790 days. However the simulation run shown in Fig 7b reveals the risk of a far greater epidemic impact, despite identical parameters controlling disease spread and control. A small proportion of asymptomatic but infectious trees escape control on each round of removal, and this leads to widespread disease. Nearly 90% of hosts (1743 out of 2000) are eventually removed before the pathogen is fully controlled at t = 4300d. Similar behaviour is easily observable via the interface ( cf. Fig 7c, which shows typical histograms summarising the final state of 500 runs using the default parameterisation).
